captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
AMG has made a hot hatchback.

It's called the A45, and it
is extremely expensive.

But then its specification
is quite special.

It has a lot of power, and
it's four-wheel drive.

It's natural rival is the BMW
M135i, a cheaper car that's

less powerful, but which
is rear-wheel drive and
potentially even more fun.

So seconds out, round
one on the road,
round two on the track.
Let's find a winner!
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

The first time you even sit in
the A45 and you experience it

accelerate in second and third
gear, you will say [BLEEP]
me.
That's a fast car.

It's quite a confusing machine
to start with.

I'm starting to deconstruct
it and understand it
a bit better now.

But I have to say, to start
with, I thought
what's this all about?

First up, it is magnificently,
splendidly fast.

And it's got that kind of
point-to-point performance

that we associate with
Evos and Imprezas.

But it's got a Mercedes
badge on it.

So first of all, you think is
this a Mercedes-Benz at all?

Because it doesn't really square
with any of the brand
values you expect.

It's small, with short
overhangs, quite a long wheel

base related to its
overall size.

It's agile, and it just extracts
performance from the

road surface in a way that
you don't expect.

It's remarkable just
how fast it is.

And then you try and think
about what's going on.

Because for nearly 40,000
pounds, you've got this

turbocharged four-cylinder
engine.

And it doesn't make the best
noise in the world, if I'm
honest with you.
But on up-shifts--
oh, here we go.

First to second, second
to third, here we go--
bang.

You get these massive cracks
on the up-shift,
which are so exciting.
It's a mechanical noise.
It's a great noise.
Is it a 40,000 noise?
I'm not so sure.

Other things that surprise
about it.

Well, first off I thought,
the ride's too harsh.

The right is just a bit
too firm for me.

And it is firm, but the faster
you go, the more you

appreciate the fact there's
some real quality damping
behind that firmness.

So I'll go back from harsh
and say it's firm.

It's about as far as I
want the car to be.

But actually the harder you
push, the better it gets.

And that's interesting in the
context of the BMW, which
we'll come to afterwards.

There's not much life to the
steering really, not much to
be enjoyed there.

There's quite a lot
to be enjoyed in
the gearbox, though.

This is Mercedes' own
double-clutch unit and it's

fast on up-shifts, very fast on
up-shifts, a slight delay
on the paddle.

It's more responsive to the
paddle on down shifts.

But in any case, it's
a fast gearbox.

And in combination with this
engine, you suddenly feel like

you're in a four-cylinder
racing car or something.

It's quite Touring
car in feel--
Rev it out, pull on a paddle--
BANG!
Shift, move again.

Brake pedal firm, brakes
fantastic on the road.

We'll find out more when we do
some circuit work later on.

Interestingly, the engine
doesn't just produce a slab of
torque low down.

Yes, it's pulling hard
from anything
above about 1,800 rpm.

But there's this real kick point
at about 5 and 1/2 into

about 6 and 1/2, which
I hadn't expected.

So in that respect,
it does feel a bit
revvier than the BMW.
Hm.
Is it a 40,000 car?

Can this car justify being more
than a Porsche Boxter?

In some ways, I don't
think it can.

I mean, there are bits of
the cabin that just
don't justify the price.

This plastic down the center
console is hard and brittle
and will scratch.

However, above kind of testicle
height, the rest of
the cabin--
pretty pleasing to me.
I don't know.

I shouldn't be the judge
of aesthetics.

But it doesn't look like they've
scrimped too much.
It feels pretty high quality.
I like the compact size.

What is so surprising is the
way it covers ground is
mind-blowing.

If you're in an M3 or in a C63
on any kind of B-road in the

UK, don't even attempt to stay
with an A45, because
you will fall off.

Now we mustn't forget that the
A45 AMG is a full-house

bespoked performance model,
but the M135i
isn't a proper M car.

Still, as tested, the Merc cost
42,525 pounds, with some

eye-popping prices for
the carbon bits.

These body trimmings are
2,550 pounds, and the
carbon mirrors are--
wait for it--
1,230 pounds.

Power is rated at 360
horsepower, torque at 332.

The curb weight is
1,555 kilograms.

The 135i has just become a
little more expensive in the
UK, but not much.

Its basic price, as a
three-door, is 30,570 pounds,

still over 7,000 less than
the Merc is standard .

However, once you've opted for
the amazing 8-speed auto, the

adaptive dampers and, well, some
other trinkets, you end

up with a car which doesn't feel
that well specified and

which costs a nip
under 38,000.

It's a little down on power with
320, but matches the 332
foot-pounds of the A45.

And the 135 is 55 kilograms
lighter.

Is BMW, with its rather
wonderful M135i, playing the

marketing headlines game
a bit too cutely?

I don't think it is, but these
are the facts as they stand.

Yes, you can buy the car for
under 30,000 pounds.

But if you add the gearbox,
the wonderful 8-speed ZF

automatic gearbox, that's
another 3,000 pounds.

If you add the adaptive damping,
it's another xxxx.
We can go on.

So let's think of this as a
34,000-pound car, and not a

29,000-pound car, to keep
everyone on the
forums happy, OK?

I'm thinking of it as
a 34,000-pound car.

Well, to my eyes, it's a
compact, incredibly capable,
very fast, very exciting,
beautiful-sounding package for 34,000.

I still think it's the bargain
of the century.

And I still think it makes the
Mercedes look expensive.
This engine--
wow!

Well, Mercedes has done some
incredible work to extract all

that usable power and
performance from its

4-cylinder motor and its
double-clutch gearbox.

But I hate to say it, to live
with, this BMW 6 has a more
pleasant engine.
It's got a bit more torque.

To me, it revs a bit
more sweetly.

It makes the most lovely,
lovely classic BMW
straight-six noise.

I know it's a little bit
synthesized in places.

So what's wrong with
the M135i?

Well, I've discovered
something today.

I've been driving it over
some really, really
tough, bumpy roads.

And I don't mean kind
of a bit bumpy.
I mean very harsh.

And I think I found the point at
which the suspension says,
nope, I've had enough.

I had it in comfort mode,
and it felt a bit loose.

I put it into sport mode, and
it felt like the back axle

wasn't that well located into
the body, like all the
bushings were a bit too soft.

And where the Mercedes got
better and better as I pushed

it over those hard roads, well,
the BMW, I found its
limits a bit.

But that was fast driving, a
kind of 7 and 8/10, which in

this car means you're covering
ground at an indecent speed.
This car is lovely.

It's got this quite fast
steering rack.
It's agile.
It makes that lovely noise.
It has that transmission.

You do think to yourself,
what more could I want?

And it's in a compact body
as well, so it's wieldy.
It's quite small.
You can use that performance.

Is the rear-wheel drive
thing a bonus?

To me, yes, because you can
make it do these little

squiggles coming
out of corners.
Neil, put a squiggle in now.
Good, you've seen a squiggle.
And I rather enjoy those.

I know they're not very good for
some people, but the car

does feel rear-driven when
you get up there.
And I quite like that.

You get to make the
odd correction.

You do get some understeer
in the Mercedes.

We'll find that again on track
later on how they differ, but

on the road, on balance, I
quite like the rear-wheel
drive thing.

So I don't know how
to judge that.

What about how I feel
inside the car
compared to the Mercedes?

Well, just like the Merc, you
can pick a few holes.

There's some hard plastics
down here.

Again, it's another car that's
being stretched into a bigger

price category because
of its performance.
And you can pick holes.

Fundamentally, it's a
good cabin, though.

It's probably, to more
people, the more
pleasant place to sit.
But who am I to judge that?

I think the instrumentation is
very clear, but so do I in the
Mercedes-Benz.

No, I find it very difficult
to find much
wrong with this car.

But yeah, bumpy roads, maybe
not its favorite thing if

you're going absolutely
flat out.

This ZF gearbox is a
triumph, though.
It shifts so fast.

It's so good in automatic
mode.

I know Mercedes has spent
lots of time and money--
specifically AMG Mercedes--

on making that double clutch
as good as it is.

But in some respects, it can't
quite match the sheer

smoothness and speed
of this unit.

Before we start in the A45 at
the wonderful little Landau

circuit, let's look at
whether we've got any
buttons to play with.

Interestingly, there are not
many buttons to play with.

I'm got an off button, which
turns all the traction off.

Naturally, I've done that, so
no stability, no traction.

Gearbox just goes to manual, so
I can do paddles myself and
it will hold a gear.

Other than that, there
are no buttons.

As someone who doesn't really
like gimmicky buttons, I feel
that's very refreshing.

But oddly, I'm now sitting here
thinking there's nothing
to play with.

There's no pleasing some
people, is there?
Out.
Onto the circuit.
Gear shift.
Fast.
Steering.
Good weighting.

As you'd expect, pretty
sensational traction, and then
you let it go over 5 and 1/2.
It just strolls along.
It keeps pulling.
Very smooth for a 4-cylinder.

And I love those cracks
on the up-shift.
They are just fantastic.
Great over the curves.

And the brake pedal for
me, it's a stand-out
point of the car.

I hadn't expected it, but the
brake pedal is just so
reassuring.

From a high speed, you hit
it with real confidence.

And the brakes themselves--
superb.

I mean, again, I didn't expect
it to be such a stand-out
feature of the car.
Down shifts?

Good, but it needs a car that
you've got to overstop,

because you think you
can catch the next
gear, and it won't.

And you'll think it's not
changed down fast enough.

It's because you were
traveling too
fast to get the gear.
Haldex--

well, we all know about the
evils of the Haldex 4-wheel
drive system.

This car slightly exposes the
Volkswagen-Audi group, because

Mercedes has done a much
better job with this.

Ultimately, the car does
understeer, but it's nothing

like that horrible terminal
understeer you get in an RS3.

Give it full power on the exit
of a fast turn, and it will
begin to neutralize.
And the slower stuff?

Yeah, it never feels like the
back wheels are doing an awful
lot of driving in the dry.

But god, it's not getting in
the way of me having fun.
And it's massively fast.
I mean, massively fast.
The car just turns.

As for lap times, well, we'll
discuss those in a minute.
Can I make this car oversteer?

In the dry, I'm afraid
I can't.

What I can do now and again is
being a bit brutal with the
direction change.
I can throw the car in.

And the car will just
begin to neutralize.
The back axle will step out.

But no, it's not a car that I
can just play with a la Evo.

A little bit of brake helps
bring it around as well.

But I'm surprised at how much
I enjoy its neutrality.

I keep coming back to how
fast it is, though.
This power tranny is just--
immense.
It's so immense.
It feels like a special car.
And it's fast.

And the more I drive it, the
more I like this quite sort of
hard-edged, 4-cylinder noise.

And the exhaust fan tops,
I really like those.
Steering?
Hmm.
They've done a great job here.

We've got really
nice weighting.
I'm enjoying it.

In fact, I prefer the controls
to this car much more than I
do the BMW's.

I think the brake pedal and the
steering especially really

do give you a confidence that
in the BMW you haven't got.

Of course, if you spend a bit
more time in the BMW, it comes
to meet you.

Let's go and have a
go in that one.
[ENGINE ROARING]

It can be so interesting, but
also so dangerous to jump from

a car like the A45 straight
into the 135i, because

initially, the car feels
very, very numb.

The steering wheel feels
too big and squishy.

The brake pedal feels like
it's not responsive.

The whole car feels quite loose
and lazy in a way that
the Mercedes doesn't.

And then you spend a bit of
time in this car-- just do

three or four laps of Landau--
and suddenly, you realize that

you have to work with
it a little bit.
It's rear-wheel drive.

It doesn't want to attack the
apex in quite the same manner.

The steering, yes, it is strange
because it's so fast.

But you adapt to the speed
of the steering.

And then suddenly, you feel
like you can place the car
exactly where you wants to.

And then you turn the traction
control off, and you realize

that BMW have always been onto
something with this rear-wheel
drive lark.
The engine-- ho, ho, ho, ho.

It's a bit of a kind of baby
super car in some respects.

Because this, to me, feels like
a monumental powertrain

wedged into this slightly
gawky body.

And all the time, the engine
dominates, this incredible

noise you're hearing,
the induction noise.
It's just fantastic.
And it revs out.

It just loves to rev. It doesn't
actually go as well as

the Mercedes at the
very top end.

But you kind of hang on to this
just to enjoy the noise.

Brake pedal, even when you get
used to it, doesn't have that

massive reassurance
the AMG does.

So, yeah, in some respects,
this doesn't feel like the
pucker performance product.

And in fairness, it
isn't, is it?
Because it's not an M-car.

It's an M135i, whereas the AMG
is a full AMG-spec car.
Grip?
Well, it's interesting.

We're on Michelin Pilot Super
Sports on this car, whereas

that just on Pilot 3's,
that A45 AMG.

So it should have a
big advantage in
terms of lap time.

But it doesn't, even on normal
surface the AMG is quicker

round this very technical
little circuit.

There's just something to be
said for being able to do
that, though, isn't there?
I'm always going to enjoy it.

I know it's not in any way
relevant to the ownership

prospects of this M135i, because
people don't go out
and do oversteer.

But on the road, I still love
feeling that the rear end is
doing all the work.

But the A45 is going to have an
enormous advantage in terms
of all-weather performance.

In the winter in the UK, that's
the car you're going to

want to be in to be
fast and safe.

But this is the car you want
to be in to have fun.
Open differential, though.

I wish you could tick a box that
said LSD, because even

though I can make it do things
round here, I'm having to

excite the back of the
car a bit more than
perhaps I'd like to.
I love the noise.
I love the package.

I love the vocabulary of this
new style of hot hatchback.

It's a totally new
thing, isn't it?

You get in it and the power
trains of both cars are so

impressive, you just stick them
in drive and off you go.

And then you just pull
a couple of paddles.

Strangely, I feel less robbed
in a car like this by not

having manual gearbox than I
do in something like a GT3.

It seems to suit the immediacy,
the lovely clever

packaging of a car
of this type.

Maybe I'm being too kind on
this type of car, but wow.
The performance available--
mind-blowing.

So what do they do in
a straight line?

The 135 does 60 in 4.5
seconds and 100 in an
impressive 10.9 seconds.

But the AMG is on another
level altogether.

4.2 seconds to 60 in a hatchback
and 10 dead to 100.
That is nuts.

Lap times were set at a
completely dry track.

Remember, the BMW has the
distinct advantage of a set of

sticky Michelin Super Sport
tires, and it managed a 47.7.

The A45, using normal rubber,
went even quicker, I'm afraid.

It did a 47.5, leaving us with
the question, what would it do
on cup tires?
This is very hard to call.

The 135 remains the bargain of
2013, so long as you go easy

with the options, have the
autobox and the adaptive
dampers, leave the rest.

But the A45 drives with
real precision.
It's so fast, so usable.

And even though it doesn't look
quite special enough,
it's a lovely little object.

If I had the extra cash,
I'd take the AMG.

If I didn't, I'd drive around
in an M135i, smug that I had
so much for so little.
[SQUEALING TIRES]

title: Mercedes A45 AMG v BMW M135i on Road and Track - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS
